title: About
text:
I’m Omar Mnfy, an Egyptian student passionate Computer Science and Data Science student at Pitzer College. With a strong foundation in both fields, I’m always seeking opportunities to blend my technical expertise with real-world applications. Over the past few years, I’ve taken on a variety of roles that have allowed me to dive deep into the world of technology and problem-solving.







My technical toolkit spans across multiple domains:

Programming Languages: Python, MATLAB, JavaScript, C, C++, HTML, CSS, R, SQL
Frameworks: React, Node.js, Bootstrap, WordPress, Flask
Libraries: Pandas, NumPy, TensorFlow, Scikit-learn, OpenCV, YOLO, Simulink




I currently serve as a Machine Learning Developer at P-ai (Pomona AI) in Claremont, where I apply my skills in AI and data science to real-world challenges. Additionally, I work as an AI Developer at Outlier, a freelance role where I focus on building AI solutions for diverse clients.
In the past, I have held roles such as:

Product Manager at the Randall Lewis Center for Innovation & Entrepreneurship at Claremont McKenna College, where I led projects that bridged technology and innovation.
Data Analyst at the W.M. Keck Science Department, leveraging data to support research and academic initiatives.
Data Engineering Intern at WholeRen, where I developed data pipelines and infrastructure solutions.




My academic journey has also been marked by a commitment to research, particularly at Sheung Lab, where I focus on innovative projects at the intersection of data science and engineering. I’m constantly pushing the boundaries of what AI and machine learning can do, with a keen interest in natural language processing, computer vision, and ethical AI practices.

title: Data Viz
text:
TidyTuesday Data Source


This section will load the data and create a scatter plot that compares the number of turns to player ranking. It will help explore how the duration of chess games varies based on the players’ ratings.

# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)

# Load the chess dataset using tidytuesdayR
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2024-10-01')

---- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2024-10-01 ----
--- There is 1 file available ---


── Downloading files ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1 of 1: "chess.csv"

chess <- tuesdata$chess

# Data Cleaning
chess_clean <- chess %>%
  mutate(average_rating = (white_rating + black_rating) / 2)

# Visualization: Scatter Plot of Game Turns vs Average Rating
ggplot(chess_clean, aes(x = average_rating, y = turns)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "blue") +
  labs(
    title = "Scatter Plot of Chess Game Turns vs Average Player Rating",
    x = "Average Player Rating",
    y = "Number of Turns",
    caption = "Source: Lichess dataset via TidyTuesday, 2024-10-01"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

title: Data Viz
text:
TidyTuesday Data Source


This section will load the data and create a scatter plot that compares the number of turns to player ranking. It will help explore how the duration of chess games varies based on the players’ ratings.

# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)

# Load the chess dataset using tidytuesdayR
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2024-10-01')

---- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2024-10-01 ----
--- There is 1 file available ---


── Downloading files ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1 of 1: "chess.csv"

chess <- tuesdata$chess

# Data Cleaning
chess_clean <- chess %>%
  mutate(average_rating = (white_rating + black_rating) / 2)

# Visualization: Scatter Plot of Game Turns vs Average Rating
ggplot(chess_clean, aes(x = average_rating, y = turns)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "blue") +
  labs(
    title = "Scatter Plot of Chess Game Turns vs Average Player Rating",
    x = "Average Player Rating",
    y = "Number of Turns",
    caption = "Source: Lichess dataset via TidyTuesday, 2024-10-01"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
